str:Agency.com:Name: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (PULL)
UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS)
str:Agency.com:Description: The UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS) is the statistical office of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). The Institute produces the data and methodologies to monitor trends at national and international levels. It delivers comparative data for countries at all stages of development to provide a global perspective on education, science and technology, culture, and communication. The UIS is the official source for the indicators needed to achieve SDG 4–Education 2030 and key targets in science and innovation, culture and communication.

str:Contact.com:Name: UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS)
str:Contact.str:Role: Single entry point for external inquiries

str:Agency.com:Name: Metadata Technology
str:Agency.com:Description: Provider of consultancy, software, and services to the SDMX community.

str:Agency.com:Name: International Labour Organization
str:Agency.com:Description:
The ILO was founded in 1919, in the wake of a destructive war, to pursue a vision based on the premise that universal, lasting peace can be established only if it is based on social justice. The ILO became the first specialized agency of the UN in 1946.
The main aims of the ILO are to promote rights at work, encourage decent employment opportunities, enhance social protection and strengthen dialogue on work-related issues.

str:Agency.com:Name: The Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics
Nigerian National Bureau of Statistics (NBS)
str:Agency.com:Description: The National Bureau of Statistics Nigeria as the mandate to generate, on a continuous and sustainable basis, socio-economic statistics on all facets of development in Nigeria.

str:Agency.com:Name: National Statistical Institute of Guinea-Bissau - Instituto Nacional de Estatística da Guiné-Bissau (INE)
Statistical Centre for the Cooperation Council for the Arab Countries of the Gulf
str:Agency.com:Description: Statistical Centre for the Cooperation Council for the Arab Countries of the Gulf

str:Code.com:Name: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands
Pacific Islands, Trust Territory of the
St Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha
Euro area (Member States and Institutions of the Euro Area) changing composition
Immediate counterparty basis
str:Code.com:Description: Methodology whereby positions are allocated to the primary party to a contract. In the CBS, claims on an immediate counterparty basis are allocated to the country and sector of the entity to which the funds were lent.

str:Code.com:Name: Outward risk transfers
str:Code.com:Description: Outward risk transfers reallocate claims out of the country of the immediate counterparty.

str:Code.com:Name: Inward risk transfers
str:Code.com:Description: Inward risk transfers reallocate claims into the country of the guarantor.

str:Code.com:Name: Net risk transfers (Inward-Outward)
str:Code.com:Description: Inward minus outward risk transfers.

str:Code.com:Name: Guarantor basis
str:Code.com:Description: Methodology whereby positions are allocated to a third party that has contracted to assume the debts or obligations of the primary party if that party fails to perform. In the CBS, claims on a guarantor basis are allocated to the country and sector of the entity that guarantees the claims (or, in the case of claims on branches, the country of the parent bank).

str:Code.com:Name: Secondary confidentiality set by the sender, not for publication
Not for publication, restricted for internal use only
Secondary confidentiality set and managed by the receiver, not for publication
Sum of ECU, Euro and legacy currencies now included in the Euro
All currencies excluding USD, EUR and JPY
All currencies excl. core
str:Code.com:Description: All currencies excluding core (ie USD, EUR, JPY, CHF and GBP)

str:Code.com:Name: Merrill Lynch Multi Currency
str:Code.com:Description: Merrill Lynch Multi Currency for ICS data loading

str:Code.com:Name: Bond Markets Unit European Composite Unit (EURCO)
Bond Markets Unit European Monetary Unit (E.M.U.-6)
Bond Markets Unit European Unit of Account 9 (E.U.A.-9)
Bond Markets Unit European Unit of Account 17 (E.U.A.-17)

ECB / SEC All currencies other than domestic, Euro and MU currencies
ECB / SEC Euro and Greek Drachma
ECB / SEC Other currencies except Greek Drachma
Total (all maturities)
str:Code.com:Description: Sum of all maturities.

str:Code.com:Name: Short-term
str:Code.com:Description: Having a maturity up to and including one year or on demand.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 1 year and up to 5 years
str:Code.com:Description: Between one and five years.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 5 years
str:Code.com:Description: More than five years.

str:Code.com:Name: 7 days or less
str:Code.com:Description: Up to seven days.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 7 days and up to 1 month
str:Code.com:Description: Over seven days and up to one month. Market conventions: 2W (two weeks), 1M (one month).

str:Code.com:Name: Over 1 month and up to 3 months
str:Code.com:Description: Over one month and up to three months. Market conventions: 3M (three months).

str:Code.com:Name: Long-term
str:Code.com:Description: Having a maturity greater than one year.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 3 months and up to 1 year
Over 1 year and up to and including 2 years
str:Code.com:Description: Claims with a remaining maturity over one year and up to and including two years.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 2 years
str:Code.com:Description: Claims with a remaining maturity over two years.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 7 days and up to 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: Between seven days and one year.

str:Code.com:Name: Up to and including 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: Short-term.

str:Code.com:Name: Over 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: Long-term.

str:Code.com:Name: Unallocated by maturity
str:Code.com:Description: Claims for which the remaining maturity is unknown, or claims that cannot be classified by maturity (eg equities and participations).

str:Code.com:Name: Over 3 months and up to 6 months
str:Code.com:Description: Over three months and up to six months. Market conventions: 6M (six months).

str:Code.com:Name: Over 6 months
str:Code.com:Description: Over six months. Market conventions: 9M (nine months), 1Y (one year).

str:Code.com:Name: One day
str:Code.com:Description: One day. Market conventions: O/N (overnight), T/N (tomorrow next), S/N (spot next).

str:Code.com:Name: Over 1 day and less than 7 days
str:Code.com:Description: Over one day and up to seven days. Market conventions: S/W (spot week), 1W (one week).

str:Code.com:Name: Unallocated maturity of seven days or less
str:Code.com:Description: Up to seven days.

str:Code.com:Name: Debt securities
str:Code.com:Description: Negotiable instrument serving as evidence of a debt. Debt securities include the following instruments: bills, bonds, notes, negotiable certificates of deposit, commercial paper, debentures, asset-backed securities, money market instruments and similar instruments normally traded in financial markets.

str:Code.com:Name: Loans and deposits
str:Code.com:Description: Non-negotiable debt instruments that are created when a creditor lends funds directly to a debtor. In the LBS, no distinction is made between loans and deposits; they are treated as economically equivalent. Loans and deposits include the cash leg of securities repurchase agreements, working capital and inter-office business.

str:Code.com:Name: Derivatives
str:Code.com:Description: HIE_BIS_LBS_DISS_L_INSTR whose value depends on some underlying financial asset, commodity or predefined variable.

str:Code.com:Name: Local claims
str:Code.com:Description: Local claims are claims on counterparties located in the same country as the banking group’s entity that books the position.

str:Code.com:Name: Total claims
str:Code.com:Description: A claim is a financial asset that has a counterpart liability. In the CBS, claims exclude financial derivatives. See also "financial asset".

str:Code.com:Name: Cross-border claims
str:Code.com:Description: Cross-border claims are positions on counterparties located outside the country where the entity that books the position is located.

str:Code.com:Name: Total assets (financial and non-financial)
str:Code.com:Description: Sum of financial assets and non-financial assets.

str:Code.com:Name: International claims
str:Code.com:Description: Claim on a non-resident or denominated in a foreign currency. International claims comprise cross-border claims in any currency plus local claims of foreign affiliates denominated in non-local currencies.

str:Code.com:Name: Claims on banks with head offices outside host country
Capital / equity
str:Code.com:Description: Includes common shares, preferred shares, retained earning

str:Code.com:Name: Local liabilities
str:Code.com:Description: Local liabilities are liabilities on counterparties located in the same country as the banking group’s entity that books the position.

str:Code.com:Name: Net positions
str:Code.com:Description: Claims minus liabilities

str:Code.com:Name: Foreign Claims
str:Code.com:Description: Claim on residents of countries other than the country where the controlling parent is located, ie a claim of a domestic bank on non-residents of the reporting country. Foreign claims comprise local claims of the bank's offices abroad as well as crossborder claims of the bank's offices worldwide.

str:Code.com:Name: Guarantees extended
str:Code.com:Description: Contingent liabilities that arise from an irrevocable obligation to pay a third-party beneficiary when a client fails to perform certain contractual obligations. Guarantees extended include the notional value of credit protection sold.

str:Code.com:Name: Credit commitments
str:Code.com:Description: Promise by a creditor to lend up to a specified amount to a borrower on demand. In the CBS, credit commitments refer to commitments that are irrevocable unilaterally by the creditor, ie revocable only with the consent of the borrower.

str:Code.com:Name: Other potential exposures
str:Code.com:Description: Sum of derivatives contracts, guarantees extended and credit commitments

str:Code.com:Name: Banks, total
str:Code.com:Description: Business between banks. In the LBS, "interbank" typically refers to business between banking offices and thus includes inter-office business.

str:Code.com:Name: Non-financial corporations
str:Code.com:Description: Entity whose principal activity is the production of market goods or non-financial services. Non-financial corporations include the following entities: legally constituted corporations, branches of non-resident enterprises, quasi-corporations, notional resident units owning land, and resident non-profit institutions that are market producers of goods or non-financial services.

str:Code.com:Name: Non-bank financial institutions
str:Code.com:Description: Financial institution, other than a bank, engaged primarily in the provision of financial services and activities auxiliary to financial intermediation, such as fund management. Non-bank financial corporations include the following entities: special purpose vehicles, hedge funds, securities brokers, money market funds, pension funds, insurance companies, financial leasing corporations, CCPs, unit trusts, other financial auxiliaries and other captive financial institutions. They also include any public financial institutions such as development banks and export credit agencies.

str:Code.com:Name: General government
str:Code.com:Description: Sectoral classification that refers collectively to the central government, state government, local government and social security funds. General government excludes the central bank and publicly owned corporations.

str:Code.com:Name: Households and NPISHs
str:Code.com:Description: Group of persons who share the same living accommodation, who pool some or all of their income and wealth, and who consume certain types of goods and services collectively, mainly housing and food. In the LBS and CBS, the household sector refers collectively to households and non-profit institutions serving households.

str:Code.com:Name: Banks, related offices
str:Code.com:Description: Entities that are part of the same banking group, ie that are within the perimeter of consolidation of the controlling parent institution. Includes the controlling parent institution, the head office of the bank (if different), and branches or subsidiaries that are part of the consolidated reporting entity.

str:Code.com:Name: Banks, unrelated banks
str:Code.com:Description: Entities that stay outside a banking group (ie do not have the same consolidated reporting entity).

str:Code.com:Name: Banks, central banks
str:Code.com:Description: Central banks; currency boards or independent currency authorities that issue national currency that is fully backed by foreign exchange reserves; government-affiliated agencies that are separate institutional units and primarily perform central bank activities; and international organisations that undertake activities similar to those of central banks.

str:Code.com:Name: Non-banks, total
str:Code.com:Description: Entity that is not a bank. Sectoral classification that refers collectively to non-bank financial corporations and the non-financial sector.

str:Code.com:Name: Official sector
str:Code.com:Description: Sectoral classification used in the CBS that refers collectively to general government, central banks and international organisations.

str:Code.com:Name: Non-financial sectors
str:Code.com:Description: Sectoral classification that refers collectively to non-financial corporations, general government and households.

str:Code.com:Name: Non-bank private sector
str:Code.com:Description: Sectoral classification used in CBS that refers collectively to non-bank financial corporations, non-financial corporations and households, ie the non-bank sector excluding general government.

str:Code.com:Name: Non-financial private sector
str:Code.com:Description: Sectoral classification that refers collectively to non-financial corporations and households, ie the non-financial sector excluding general government.

str:Code.com:Name: Missing value; data exist but were not collected
FX and break adjusted change (BIS calculated)
str:Code.com:Description: Change in amount outstanding between two points in time after the impact of methodological changes and exchange rate movements has been eliminated. The adjusted change approximates the flow between two points in time. In the LBS, the adjusted change is calculated by first converting US dollar-equivalent amounts outstanding into their original currency using end-of-period exchange rates, then calculating the difference in amounts outstanding in the original currency, and finally converting the difference into a US dollar-equivalent change using average period exchange rates.

str:Code.com:Name: Amounts outstanding / Stocks
str:Code.com:Description: Value of an asset or liability at a point in time.

str:Code.com:Name: Break in stocks
str:Code.com:Description: Changes in assets and liabilities between opening and closing balance sheets that are due neither to transactions between institutional units nor to changes in value. (MFSM, 193)

str:Code.com:Name: Annual growth (BIS calculated)
str:Code.com:Description: In the LBS and in the GLI, quarterly growth rates compounded over four quarters.

str:Codelist.com:Name: Submission channel
str:Codelist.com:Description: This codelist contains values for the different submission channels

str:Codelist.com:Name: Possible formats for representation of dates, times or dateranges

str:Concept.com:Name: Data type (vis-a-vis sector / maturity / risk transfers etc.)
Data type (amounts outstanding, net disbursement or changes)
Business sector of ultimate issuer, measure
Other PS's net value/volume that settle in the PS in question
